ğŸœ

behavior.append: name="$[name]" depends="$[depends]" if="$[if]" unless="$[unless]" description="$[description]" extensionOf="$[extension of]" onMissingExtensionPoint="$[on missing extension point]"> </${completion}>

ğŸœ

ğŸœ
ğŸœ
ğŸœ Expands a file packed using GZip.
ğŸœ Expands a file packed using BZip2.
ğŸœ Expands a file packed using XZ.
ğŸœ Packs a file using the GZip algorithm. This task does not do any dependency checking; the output file is always generated.
ğŸœ Packs a file using the BZip2 algorithm. This task does not do any dependency checking; the output file is always generated.
ğŸœ Packs a file using the XZ algorithm. This task does not do any dependency checking; the output file is always generated.

ğŸœ Creates Microsoft CAB archive files. It is invoked similar to the Jar or Zip tasks. This task will work on Windows using the external cabarc tool (provided by Microsoft), which must be located in your executable path.
ğŸœ An extension of the Jar task with special treatment for files that should end up in an Enterprise Application archive.
ğŸœ Jars a set of files.
ğŸœ Use the `zipfileset` and `zipgroupfileset` attributes of the Jar or Zip tasks instead.
ğŸœ Creates a manifest file.
ğŸœ Invokes the `rpm` executable to build a Linux installation file. This task currently only works on Linux or other Unix platforms with RPM support.
ğŸœ Signs a jar or zip file with the `javasign` command-line tool.
ğŸœ Creates a tar archive.
ğŸœ Unzips a jarfile.
ğŸœ Untars a tarfile.
ğŸœ Unzips a warfile.
ğŸœ Unzips a zipfile.
ğŸœ An extension of the Jar task with special treatment for files that should end up in the `WEB-INF/lib`, `WEB-INF/classes`, or `WEB-INF` directories of the Web Application Archive.
ğŸœ Invokes the JDepend parser. This parser "traverses a set of Java source-file directories and generates design-quality metrics for each Java package".

ğŸœ Determines which class files are out-of-date with respect to their source, removing the class files of any other classes that depend on the out-of-date classes, forcing the re-compile of the removed class files. Typically used in conjunction with the Javac task.
ğŸœ Compiles the specified source file(s) within the running (Ant) JVM, or in another JVM if the fork attribute is specified.

ğŸœ Runs the JSP compiler. It can be used to precompile JSP pages for fast initial invocation of JSP pages, deployment on a server without the full JDK installed, or simply to syntax-check the pages without deploying them. The Javac task can be used to compile the generated Java source. (For WebLogic JSP compiler, see the Wljspc task.)
ğŸœ Compiles a NetRexx source tree within the running (Ant) JVM.
ğŸœ Runs the `rmic` compiler on the specified file(s).
ğŸœ Compiles JSP pages using WebLogic JSP compiler, `weblogic.jspc`. (For non-WebLogic JSP compiler, see the JspC task.
ğŸœ Runs a "hot" deployment tool for vendor-specific J2EE server.
ğŸœ Generates code documentation using the `javadoc` tool. The Javadoc2 task is deprecated; use the Javadoc task instead.
ğŸœ Runs Ant on a supplied buildfile, optionally passing properties (with possibly new values). This task can be used to build sub-projects.
ğŸœ Runs another target within the same buildfile, optionally passing properties (with possibly new values).
ğŸœ Executes a system command. When the os attribute is specified, the command is only executed when Ant is run on one of the specified operating systems.
ğŸœ Use Apply instead
ğŸœ Compares a set of source files with a set of target files. If any of the source files is newer than any of the target files, all the target files are removed.
ğŸœ Executes a system command. When the os attribute is specified, the command is only executed when Ant is run on one of the specified operating systems.
ğŸœ Executes a Java class within the running (Ant) JVM, or in another JVM if the fork attribute is specified.
ğŸœ A container task that can contain other Ant tasks. Each nested task specified within the <parallel> tag will be executed in its own thread.

ğŸœ A container task that can contain other Ant tasks. The nested tasks are simply executed in sequence. Its primary use is to support the sequential execution of a subset of tasks within the <parallel> tag.
ğŸœ Suspends execution for a specified period of time. Useful when a build or deployment process requires an interval between tasks.
ğŸœ Calls a given target for all defined sub-builds. This is an extension of ant for bulk project execution.
ğŸœ Blocks execution until a set of specified conditions become true. This task is intended to be used with the Parallel task to synchronize a set of processes.
ğŸœ Changes the permissions and/or attributes of a file or all files inside the specified directories. Currently, it has effect only under Windows.
ğŸœ Generates a checksum for a file or set of files. This task can also be used to perform checksum verifications.
ğŸœ Changes the group ownership of a file or all files inside the specified directories. Currently, it has effect only under Unix.

ğŸœ Changes the permissions of a file or all files inside the specified directories. Currently, it has effect only under Unix. The permissions are also UNIX style, like the arguments for the `chmod` command.
ğŸœ Changes the owner of a file or all files inside the specified directories. Currently, it has effect only under Unix.
ğŸœ Concatenates multiple files into a single one or to Ant's logging system.
ğŸœ Copies a file or Fileset to a new file or directory.
ğŸœ Use the Copy task instead.
ğŸœ Use the Copy task instead.
ğŸœ Deletes either a single file, all files and sub-directories in a specified directory, or a set of files specified by one or more FileSets.
ğŸœ
ğŸœ Sets a token filter for this project, or reads multiple token filters from a specified file and sets these as filters. Token filters are used by all tasks that perform file-copying operations.
ğŸœ Modifies a file to add or remove tabs, carriage returns, linefeeds, and EOF characters.
ğŸœ Gets a file from a URL.
ğŸœ Creates a directory. Non-existent parent directories are created, when necessary.
ğŸœ Moves a file to a new file or directory, or a set(s) of file(s) to a new directory.
ğŸœ Applies a "diff" file to originals.
ğŸœ Use the Move task instead.
ğŸœ Use the Move task with a glob mapper instead.
ğŸœ Replaces the occurrence of a given string with another string in a file or set of files.
ğŸœ Replaces the occurrence of a given regular expression with a substitution pattern in a file or set of files.
ğŸœ Changes the permissions of a collection of resources.
ğŸœ Synchronizes two directory trees.
ğŸœ Generates a name for a new temporary file and sets the specified property to that name.
ğŸœ Changes the modification time of a file and possibly creates it at the same time.
ğŸœ Checks whether an extension is present in a FileSet or an ExtensionSet. If the extension is present, the specified property is set.
ğŸœ Displays the "Optional Package" and "Package Specification" information contained within the specified jars.

ğŸœ Generates a manifest that declares all the dependencies in manifest. The dependencies are determined by looking in the specified path and searching for Extension/Optional Package specifications in the manifests of the jars.
ğŸœ Tries to locate a jar to satisfy an extension, and places the location of the jar into the specified property.
ğŸœ Runs a listener that records the logging output of the build process events to a file. Several recorders can exist at the same time. Each recorder is associated with a file.
ğŸœ Sends SMTP email.
ğŸœ Use the Mail task instead.
ğŸœ Modifies the list of default exclude patterns from within your build file.
ğŸœ Echoes text to `System.out` or to a file.
ğŸœ Exits the current build by throwing a `BuildException`, optionally printing additional information.
ğŸœ Generates a key in keystore.
ğŸœ Sets properties related to the provided host, or to the host the process is run on.
ğŸœ Allows user interaction during the build process by displaying a message and reading a line of input from the console.
ğŸœ Executes a script in a Apache BSF-supported language.
ğŸœ Plays a sound file at the end of the build, according to whether the build failed or succeeded.
ğŸœ Displays a splash screen.
ğŸœ Executes a series of SQL statements via JDBC to a database. Statements can either be read in from a text file using the src attribute, or from between the enclosing SQL tags.
ğŸœ Adds a task definition to the current project, such that this new task can be used in the current project.
ğŸœ Sets the `DSTAMP`, `TSTAMP`, and `TODAY` properties in the current project, based on the current date and time.
ğŸœ Adds a data-type definition to the current project, such that this new type can be used in the current project.
ğŸœ Checks that XML files are valid (or only well-formed). This task uses the XML parser that is currently used by Ant by default, but any SAX1/2 parser can be specified, if needed.
ğŸœ Invokes the ANTLR Translator generator on a grammar file.
ğŸœ Generates a DTD for Ant buildfiles that contains information about all tasks currently known to Ant.
ğŸœ Imports another build file and potentially overrides targets in it with targets of your own.
ğŸœ Includes another build file.
ğŸœ Invokes the JavaCC compiler-compiler on a grammar file.
ğŸœ Generates JNI headers from a Java class.

ğŸœ Invokes the JJDoc documentation generator for the JavaCC compiler-compiler. JJDoc takes a JavaCC parser specification and produces documentation for the BNF grammar. It can operate in three modes, determined by command line options. This task only invokes JJDoc if the grammar file is newer than the generated BNF grammar documentation.

ğŸœ Invokes the JJTree preprocessor for the JavaCC compiler-compiler. It inserts parse-tree building actions at various places in the JavaCC source that it generates. The output of JJTree is run through JavaCC to create the parser. This task only invokes JJTree if the grammar file is newer than the generated JavaCC file.
ğŸœ Defines a new task as a macro built-up upon other tasks.
ğŸœ Converts files from native encodings to ASCII with escaped Unicode. A common usage is to convert source files maintained in a native operating system encoding to ASCII, prior to compilation.
ğŸœ Defines a new task by instrumenting an existing task with default values for attributes or child elements.
ğŸœ Identifies keys in files, delimited by special tokens, and translates them with values read from resource bundles.
ğŸœ Processes a set of documents via XSLT.
ğŸœ Sets a property if a specified file, directory, class in the classpath, or JVM system resource is available at run time.
ğŸœ Sets a property to the last element of a specified path.
ğŸœ Helps tracking build numbers.
ğŸœ Sets a property if a certain condition holds true; this is a generalization of Available and Uptodate.
ğŸœ Sets a property to the value of the specified file up to, but not including, the last path element.
ğŸœ Lists the current properties.
ğŸœ Loads a file into a property.

ğŸœ Loads a file's contents as Ant properties. This task is equivalent to using `<property file="..."/>` except that it supports nested `<filterchain>`` elements, and it cannot be specified outside a target.
ğŸœ Creates a URL (list) from a file/fileset or path

ğŸœ Converts a nested path, path reference, filelist reference, or fileset reference to the form usable on a specified platform and/or to a list of items separated by the specified separator and stores the result in the specified property.
ğŸœ Sets a property (by name and value) in the project.
ğŸœ Sets a set of properties (from a file) in the project.
ğŸœ Sets a set of properties (from a resource) in the project.

ğŸœ Creates or modifies property files. Useful when wanting to make unattended modifications to configuration files for application servers and applications. Typically used for things such as automatically generating a build number and saving it to a build properties file, or doing date manipulation.
ğŸœ Sets a property if a given target file is newer than a set of source files.
ğŸœ Finds a class or resource.
ğŸœ Loads property values from a well-formed XML file.
ğŸœ Implements a basic FTP client that can send, receive, list, and delete files, and create directories.
ğŸœ Automates a `rexec` session.
ğŸœ Copies files to or from a remote server using SSH.
ğŸœ Sets Java's HTTP proxy properties, so that tasks and code run in the same JVM can have access to remote web sites through a firewall.
ğŸœ Executes a command on a remote server using SSH.
ğŸœ Automates a `telnet` session. This task uses nested <read> and <write> tags to indicate strings to wait for and specify text to send.
ğŸœ Generates an XML report of the changes recorded in a CVS repository.
ğŸœ Generates an XML report of the changes recorded in a CVS repository
ğŸœ Adds entries to a `.cvspass` file. Adding entries to this file has the same affect as a `cvs login` command.
ğŸœ Generates an XML-formatted report file of the changes between two tags or dates recorded in a CVS repository.
ğŸœ Allows the user extract the latest edition of the source code from a PVCS repository.
ğŸœ Runs tests from the Junit testing framework. This task has been tested with JUnit 3.0 and later; it won't work with versions prior to JUnit 3.0.
ğŸœ Merges the individual XML files generated by the Junit task and applies a stylesheet on the resulting merged document to provide a browsable report of the testcases results.
